awd_titl_txt: EFRI CEE: Engineering and imaging 3D genome folding dynamics to control transcriptional misregulation in Alzheimer's disease
awd_abstract_narration:
This project seeks to discover new molecular understanding of the genetic defects in Alzheimer's disease (AD), a neurodegenerative disorder that progressively disrupts cognitive function in millions of Americans. The research team will use multi-disciplinary approaches and state-of-the-art methods to test the idea that single-base changes in genes associated with AD alter the three-dimensional (3D) packaging or folding of the genome, thereby disrupting gene activity and causing neuronal dysfunction. In parallel, they will build and test tools to re-fold pathologically tangled DNA into a configuration that will reverse some aspects of the malfunctioning genes in AD. The project will also have educational impact through development of innovative courses and training opportunities to attract and retain the highest level of next-generation talent, with a particular emphasis on under-represented minorities, for careers in the new field of genome engineering. In the long term, the research and training efforts have the potential to make positive contributions towards engineering better medicines for diseases such as AD.  

A critical unknown is how rare and common single nucleotide variants in noncoding regions of the genome govern the misregulation of gene expression that occurs in human disease. The goal of this project is to elucidate how the 3D genome and long-range gene regulation is disrupted in developing neurons by the genetic variants that cause AD. The project will focus on investigating the 3D epigenome as a new unexplored dimension in understanding and reversing the pathological transcriptional phenotypes that occur in sporadic and familial forms of AD. Cutting-edge molecular and imaging technologies will be used to query the structure and dynamics of genome folding at unprecedented resolution and scale during neural lineage commitment in healthy cells and in cells with AD mutations. The resulting outcomes will be used to build predictive models to explain how genomic miswiring is linked to pathological transcriptional disruption. Then the models will be tested by developing new engineering strategies for directing changes in genome topology on demand to reverse transcriptional defects. This work is broadly significant because it provides new quantitative models and genome engineering tools to reveal how modifications to the DNA sequence work through long-range, higher-order folding mechanisms to govern the gene expression profiles critical for proper neuron function. Addressing this knowledge gap will provide an essential foundation for the team's long-term goal to engineer the 3D genome to control neural cell fate in debilitating neurodevelopmental and neurodegenerative diseases.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
A fundamental unanswered question in genome biology is how higher-order chromatin folding shapes and is shaped by genome function. A particularly perplexing question has been the role for loops in gene expression. Two perturbative studies have shown that knock-down of the architectural protein cohesin and disruption of loops in dividing human cancer cell lines or mouse stem cells only minimally affect mRNA levels (Rao, Cell, 2014; Hsieh, Nature Genetics, 2022). Although these studies suggest that loops might not have a role in the steady-state maintenance of mRNA levels, it leaves a fundamental open question regarding the role for loops in the establishment of new gene expression patterns when human cells switch fate. Two very recent studies in Nature Genetics focused on knocking-down RNA polymerase II itself showed that indeed RNA Pol II directly matters for loop maintenance (Barshad, Nature Genetics, 2023; Zhang, Nature Genetics, 2023). Together, these data suggest that a link between loops and gene expression can be found if one uses physiologically relevant cellular models and pursues an understanding of dynamically changing RNA polymerase II or transcription establishment instead of maintenance. 

Here, we sought to examine higher-order chromatin folding, epigenetic modifications to the linear genome, and gene expression changes that occur due to rare familial Alzheimer’s disease (AD) mutations during the earliest stages of human neural lineage commitment. AD is a complex neurodegenerative disorder which presents clinically as the progressive deterioration of cognitive function and memory. Approximately 1-5% of cases are early-onset, familial (FAD), and driven by autosomal dominant, highly penetrant mutations in the amyloid precursor protein (APP) and presenilin (PSEN1/2) genes. To focus on neuron-restricted, cell autonomous molecular events, we used isogenic human induced pluripotent stem cell (iPSC) lines engineered with highly penetrant, rare FAD mutations and differentiate them into either 2D monolayer cultured post-mitotic neurons or 3D cortical organoids. We elected to focus on FAD specifically because the genetic mutations are highly penetrant and clear phenotypic changes begin early in brain development. Our approach provides a unique opportunity to examine the genome’s structure-function relationship during neural lineage commitment without confounders of different genetic backgrounds or the variation in cell type populations typical of post-mortem brain tissue.


Our study has intellectual merit and is unique from other works in the chromatin field due to the use of a physiologically relevant human post-mitotic neuron model system for 3D genome studies and the further use of nature’s perturbation of a rare neurodegeneration-causing mutation of high impact for understanding human physiology and disease. In the case of FAD, chromatin and gene expression studies in post-mortem brain tissue are rare. Furthermore, studies using post-mortem tissue are limited because late-stage tissue profiling conflates signal from multiple cell types and confounds elucidation of mechanisms that drive the initial onset of pathologic phenotypes. It is also particularly noteworthy that studies examining the role for chromatin in FAD using iPSC-derived  neurons are rare and almost non-existent due to their challenging implementation (Kwart, Neuron, 2019; Caldwell, Science Advances, 2020). Our work is unique for the use of human iPSC-derived neurons and organoids with rare FAD mutations and bulk and single-cell genomics to understand the interplay of chromatin and genetics in gene expression dysregulation in human disease.

The major findings uncovered by the publications and data produced by this study are that by integrating single-cell and bulk genomics, computational biology, and transgene overexpression experiments, we uncover a link among multi-loop miswiring, transcriptional dysregulation, and altered neural subtype fate in an early neurodevelopmental stage of FAD prior to the accumulation of classic FAD hallmarks of Aβ aggregates and tau phosphorylation. We find genome-wide miswiring of long-range chromatin loops and dysregulated gene expression in post-mitotic human neurons with a single rare, highly penetrant FAD mutation. When genes connect in FAD dynamic multi-loops, they exhibit strong changes in mRNA levels and single cell burst frequency, including the upregulation of inhibitory neural marker genes and the downregulation of excitatory neural marker genes. We also find that single loops do not predict gene expression changes, thus confirming previous reports, and highlighting the field-wide relevance of our finding that disease-dynamic multi-loops predict gene expression changes in human neurons with FAD mutations. Together, our work reveals a link among multi-loop miswiring, transcriptional dysregulation and altered neural subtype fate in an early neurodevelopmental model of FAD. These findings are important, and ahead of their time, because physiologic relevance of loops is an underexplored area.

Our work has broad impact on our understanding of the mechanistic basis and physiological relevance of the genome's structure-function relationship in human neurons. We trained 3-4 students/postdocs in this award, and they attended national and international conferences to present posters and give talks on the work. We provided extensive experimental and computational training to all of the students/postdocs, and they will graduate to roles in industry or academic research.
